metadata.title: Python vs. Node.JS: Which One is Best for Your Project? | by Claire D. Costa | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Python vs. Node.JS: Which One is Best for Your Project?
metadata.description: The reason behind this challenge is the fact that every new project comes with a unique problem, and in the world of programming, there is no such thing as a master of all trades. Different…

all_paragraphs: Choosing the right programming language when taking on a new project is perhaps one of the most daunting decisions programmers often make.

The reason behind this challenge is the fact that every new project comes with a unique problem, and in the world of programming, there is no such thing as a master of all trades. Different programming languages have their strength and weaknesses, which makes them suitable for some situations, but not all, and it’s a well-known fact that experienced programmers will agree. Throughout this article, we’ll compare Python and Node.js to identify what works better in which case.
GitHub’s second-most popular language and the most popular language for machine learning.

Python(front-end and back-end programming language) is a general-purpose, object-oriented programming language developed by Guido van Rossum that’s dynamically typed and supports multiple programming paradigms.

Python can be used to create applications for desktop, web, mobile, and comes with an exhaustive collection of packages and libraries to ease development. The convenient nature of Python makes it a perfect option for backend development, putting it among the top used programming languages.

The joy of coding Python should be in seeing short, concise, readable classes that express a lot of action in a small amount of clear code — not in reams of trivial code that bores the reader to death.

Node.js(majorly used as a backend framework) is essentially a JavaScript runtime environment created on Google Chrome’s high-performance V8 JavaScript engine, the primary contributor to improving the efficiency of Node.js code.
Developed by Ryan Dahl, Node.js is useful for building efficient and scalable web applications that run on JavaScript and can be used for both frontends as well as backend development.
In this section, we’ll do a detailed comparison of Python and Node.js with a set of pre-defined factors in mind, to give you a better understanding of both the competitors.

Python is comparatively slower in performance as it processes requests in a single flow, unlike Node.js, where advanced multithreading is possible. The use of Django may make it possible to handle high loads up to an extent, but that still doesn’t make it a viable option for mobile applications.
The efficiency and speed of Node.js code are vastly increased by the underlying snappy V8 engine, interpreting JavaScript code to machine language, delivering excellent performance.

Node.js should be your de-facto option while developing real-time web solutions, such as notification systems where mission-critical updates need to be generated and shared. Also, due to several of these optimizations, Node.js gains reduced app loading times.
Winner — Node.js takes the lead here.

In this era of smart technology, Python has been the go-to choice for trending technologies like Machine Learning, Data Science, and IoT. For ML, several tools and libraries exist along with experts in the community for those seeking help. For IoT, a pocket variant of Python exists, called MicroPython, that enables Python support for IoT devices.

Node.js is also capable of building for IoT devices, but it’s far more popular for developing web applications that include real-time communications. Node.js is being used increasingly as a server-side framework due to JavaScipt’s popularity.
Winner — The choice depends on the programmer and the type of project.

Python doesn’t come with built-in support for asynchronous programming and requires special tools to enable the functionality. One such library is asyncio, which developers can use to create asynchronous event-driven apps.

The Node.js architecture involves a single-thread event loop, which, when paired with the non-blocking nature of Node.js, allows it to handle thousands of concurrent connections without incurring thread context switching. This feature makes Node.js one of the best options for real-time web applications.
Winner — Node.js earns more points than Pythos as it provides event-driven architecture.

Python’s syntax makes it possible to write fewer lines of code to achieve more. Python is free of curly brackets, making it easier to understand and debug. With a bit of technical know-how, most people can read Python code easily, which makes it a very beginner-friendly programming language.
In terms of syntax, it is greatly similar to the browser’s JavaScript syntax, and prior knowledge with JavaScript should pose no challenge while working with Node.js.
Winner — Python wins here due to its user-friendly syntax.

Python can be used for frontend and backend cross-platform development and comes bundled with macOS and Linux. Python is a powerful programming language for web and desktop development, but it lacks in terms of mobile development, making it an impractical choice.

Node.js is also commonly used for frontend and backend development of web applications, translating to consistent use of JavaScript on both the ends. Node.js makes developing a variety of cross-platform applications, on the web, mobile, IoT, and cloud feasible, reducing development costs and efforts.
Winner — Both are capable options, and they both win here.

Python lacks proper scalability support due to a few reasons. The runtime interpretation of Python code makes it a slower programming language. Python also doesn’t support multithreading, the reason being an internal lock mechanism preventing it from running multiple tasks concurrently. But these limitations can be overcome by using Python implementations like CPython or Jython, better architectures, and load balancing mechanisms.

Node.js naturally offers scalability as it is built into the runtime environment and comes with a cluster module that is capable of handling the full power of your machine. Node.js allows for easier vertical and horizontal scaling of web applications by adding additional resources for vertical scaling and newer nodes for horizontal scaling. Additionally, scaling can be managed with below-listed strategies:
Winner — Being highly scalable compared to Python, Node.js clearly wins a point here.

Python can be comfortably extended via several frameworks such as Django, Flask, web2py, and more for full-stack as well as web-only development. Python also allows for extending features of C/C++ programming language with an API that is provided in a C source file. The pythonic implementation of Java, called Jython, can simplify scripting and enable rapid application development with ease.
Node.js comes with a pool of frameworks capable of extending its features, some of them are:
Winner — Both win here as they are equally capable.

Python makes it easier for developers to find and debug errors due to its readable and compact syntax. There is also a widespread notion that Python is generally easier and better at exception handling, giving it an upper edge when compared to Node.js.

Every programming language or runtime offers varying degrees of handling errors, as errors can occur at any point in the life cycle of an application. Similarly, Node.js is sufficiently capable of debugging errors and comes with excellent exception handling options.
Winner — Both Python and Node.js win in this aspect.

Python Packages and libraries are handled by pip, the default package installer for Python. When it comes to the number of packages, Python has more than 220 thousand packages spread across a broad range of categories such as data science, calculation, image processing, and much more, covering most of your needs.

Node.js npm, short for Node Package Manager, handles the packages in Node.js. With over 1.3 million packages, npm beats pip with a staggering amount proving how extensible node.js can be with the right package. All the packages on npm are conveniently available with a simple search.
Winner — Node.js takes the crown due to the sheer number of packages.

Python is suitable for both small and large scale projects, and more importantly, it is a critical part of the Data Science industry where the majority of tools rely on Python. Apart from that application development, Python is used in several domains, such as:

The event-based nature of Node.js makes it a perfect ingredient for applications where concurrent requests need to be handled in real-time, including frequent data transmission from the client to the server. Node.js also sees its use in real-time solutions such as:
Winner — Both competitors win due to their diverse implementations.

When it comes to finding support and useful resources online, Python has a large and helpful community. Forums offer a great place to post your queries and get advice from fellow developers while opening new doors for collaborations. Skilled developers are free to contribute to Python and its packages. For businesses, it’s a perfect place to connect with the top developers for hire.

The Node.js community is nothing short of amazing itself with its active crowd of friendly developers who are always eager to help you. The community makes it easier to showcase your talent by contributing to the open-source nature of Node.js and its various packages, even helping you find better career opportunities.
Winner — Both come with an active and helpful community.
Python has been deployed into numerous popular projects, a brief list of which is below:
Node.js is an equally capable platform and has been used in a myriad of projects, some of which are big names in the industry, such as:

Python and Node.js are very powerful options for programmers to develop web applications. Picking any one of them depends on two core factors, the purpose of the project and the skill of the developer. Of course, they both offer specific advantages over the other, but those should never outweigh the requirements of the project as there is always a way around the shortcomings. Also, it always helps to know how comfortably your team can work on either of the technologies. We hope this clears some of your doubts about Python and Node.js and brings you a step closer to picking the right option for your next project.
Note: To eliminate problems of different kinds, I want to alert you to the fact this article represents just my personal opinion I want to share, and you possess every right to disagree with it.
